11243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-008-9064-0906410.1007/s11243-008-9064-0ArticleSynthesis, characterization and crystal structures of a pair of azido-bridged polynuclear Schiff base copper(II) complexes with urease inhibitory activityYouZhong-Lu1aZhouPeng1grid.440818.1Department of Chemistry and Chemical EngineeringLiaoning Normal University116029DalianPR Chinayouzhonglu@yahoo.com.cn13220085200833445345719120081812200718120081322008© Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 20082008Abstract

A pair of azido-bridged Schiff base copper complexes, [CuL1(μ1,3-N3)]n · nClO4(1) and [Cu2(L2)2(μ1,1-N3)2] · 2ClO4(2) (L1 = N,N-diethyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, L2 = N-isopropyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine) have been obtained by the same synthetic procedures, but with slightly different Schiff bases. The structures of the complexes have been characterized by IR spectra, elemental analysis, and single crystal X-ray determination. Each Cu atom in the complexes is five-coordinate in a square pyramidal configuration involving the three N atoms of the Schiff base ligand and two N atoms from two bridging azide ligands. The azide ligands adopt end-to-end bridging mode in (1), and end-on bridging mode in (2). The different coordination modes of the azide ligands in the two complexes are assigned to the steric effects of the terminal groups (two ethyl groups for (1) and one isopropyl group for (2)) in the Schiff base ligands. The urease inhibitory activities of the complexes were evaluated. Both of them showed potent inhibition against jack bean urease.

The online version of this article (doi:10.1007/s11243-008-9064-0) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.

Introduction

Polynuclear complexes containing bridging ligands are of interest because of their versatile molecular structures, as well as the fact that they may be designed with specific functionalities [1–3]. Among pseudohalogens, azide is the most extensively studied building blocks in polynuclear complexes due to its versatility and probability of functioning as a bridging ligand to give varieties of coordination modes [4–6]. A major obstacle to a more comprehensive study of such azide-based polymeric coordination complexes is the lack of rational synthetic procedures, since with the present state of knowledge it is hardly possible to determine which coordination mode will be adopted by the azide ligand, and what final structures will be formed [7–9]. Appropriate modification of the ligands makes it possible to construct new structures of the complexes with useful properties. Recently, we have reported the urease inhibitory activities of several Schiff base complexes [10, 11]. We report herein the synthesis, crystal structures, and urease inhibitory activities of a pair of azido-bridged Schiff base copper complexes, [CuL1(μ1,3-N3)]n · nClO4(1) and [Cu2(L2)2(μ1,1-N3)2] · 2ClO4(2) (L1 = N,N-diethyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, L2 = N-isopropyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine).

ExperimentalMaterials and measurements

High purity 2-pyridylaldehyde, N,N-diethylethane-1,2-diamine, and N-isopropylethane-1,2-diamine were purchased from Aldrich and were used as received. All other reagents were of analytical grade. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) were performed using a Perkin–Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet AVATAR 360 spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4,000–400 cm−1 region.

Preparation of ligands L1 and L2

The ligands L1 and L2 were prepared by stirring equimolar amounts (1.0 mmol each) of 2-pyridylaldehyde with N,N-diethylethane-1,2-diamine, and N-isopropylethane-1,2-diamine, respectively, in 50 mL of methanol using literature methods [12, 13]. Yields: 97% for L1 and 95% for L2. Anal. Calcd. for C12H19N3 (L1): C, 70.2; H, 9.3; N, 20.5%. Found C, 70.0; H, 9.4; N, 20.4%. Anal. Calcd. for C11H17N3 (L2): C, 69.1; H, 9.0; N, 22.0%. Found C, 69.3; H, 9.1; N, 21.9%.

Preparation of [CuL1(μ<sub>1,3</sub>-N<sub>3</sub>)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> · <italic>n</italic>ClO<sub>4</sub><italic>(1)</italic>

An aqueous solution (2 mL) of copper(II) perchlorate hexahydrate (0.1 mmol) was added to a methanolic solution (8 mL) of L1 (0.1 mmol) and stirred at room temperature for 10 min. Then an aqueous solution (2 mL) of sodium azide (0.2 mmol) was added dropwise with continuous stirring. The mixture was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature to give a deep blue solution. Suitable blue single crystals for the structure determination were obtained by slow evaporation of the resulting solution in air. Yield: 67% on the basis of L1. Anal. calc. for C12H19ClCuN6O4: C, 35.13; H, 4.67; N, 20.48; found: C, 35.32; H, 4.73; N, 20.27%.

Preparation of [Cu<sub>2</sub>(L2)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>1,1</sub>-N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>] · 2ClO<sub>4</sub><italic>(2)</italic>

A procedure identical to that described for the preparation of (1), but with L1 replaced by L2, produced the blue single crystals of (2). Yield: 45% on the basis of L2. Anal. calc. for C11H17ClCuN6O4: C, 33.34; H, 4.32; N, 21.21; found: C, 33.12; H, 4.38; N, 21.33%.

X-ray crystallography

Diffraction intensities for the complexes were collected at 298(2) K using a Bruker SMART APEX 1000 area-detector with MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The collected data were reduced using the SAINT program [14], and empirical absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS program [15]. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined against F2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL program [16]. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Atom H3A attached to N3 in (2) was located in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically, with N–H distance restrained to 0.90(1) Å. All other H atoms were placed in calculated positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. The crystallographic data for the complexes are summarized in Table 1. CCDC reference numbers 638039 for (1) and 638104 for (2) (Table 2).

Urease inhibitory test

The measurement of urease inhibitory activities was carried out according to the method reported by Tanaka [17]. Generally, the assay mixture, containing 25 μL of jack bean urease (10 kU/L) and 25 μL of the tested complexes of various concentrations (dissolved in the solution of DMSO:H2O = 1:1 (v/v)), was preincubated for 1 h at 37 °C in a 96-well assay plate. Then 0.2 mL of 100 mM Hepes (N-[2-hydroxyethyl]piperazine-N′-[2-ethanesulfonic acid]) buffer at pH 6.8 [18] containing 500 mM urea and 0.002% phenol red were added and incubated at 37 °C. The reaction time, which was required to produce enough ammonium carbonate to raise the pH of a Hepes buffer from 6.8 to 7.7, was measured by a micro-plate reader (570 nm) with the end-point being determined by the color of phenol red indicator. The results concerning the inhibition of the complexes, of their corresponding ligands, and of copper(II) perchlorate on jack bean urease are summarized in Table 3.

Results and discussion

The Schiff base ligands L1 and L2 are yellow oils, that readily dissolve in methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile. The two copper complexes (as illustrated in Schemes 1 and 2) form blue block-shaped crystals, which are stable in air at room temperature, soluble in methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile, insoluble in water and diethyl ether.

The two complexes were synthesized easily under identical synthetic procedures. The synthesis of the complexes here demonstrates that the steric effects of the ligands can influence the coordination modes of the bridging azide ligands. The azide ligands in (1) adopt end-to-end coordination mode, while in (2), the azide ligands adopt end-on coordination mode, which we assign to the greater steric effects of the diethyl group of L1 compared to the isopropyl group of L2.

Structures of <italic>(1)</italic> and <italic>(2)</italic>

Figures 1 and 2 give perspective views of the complexes (1) and (2) together with the atomic labeling system. Complex (1) is an end-to-end azido-bridged polynuclear copper(II) compound, while complex (2) is a double end-on azido-bridged centrosymmetric dinuclear compound. Each Cu atom in the complexes has square pyramidal coordination and is coordinated by the three N atoms of the Schiff base ligand, and by one terminal N atom of one bridging azide ligand, defining the basal plane, and by one terminal N atom of another bridging azide ligand, occupying the apical position.

The bond lengths subtended at the metal centers are comparable with those observed in other Schiff base-copper(II) complexes [19–21]. It is notable that the apical bond lengths [2.325(3) Å for (1) and 2.536(3) Å for (2)] are much longer than those of the corresponding basal bonds (Table 1). As expected, the bonds involving amine atom N3 [2.071(3) Å for (1), 2.059(3) Å for (2)] are longer than those involving imine atom N2 [1.960(3) Å for (1), 1.954(3) Å for (2)]. Each bridging azide ligand is nearly linear and shows bent coordination mode with the metal atoms. The Cu···Cu distance is 5.659(2) Å in (1) and 3.384(2) Å in (2), respectively.

In the crystal of (1), the molecules are linked through bridging azide ligands, forming chains running along the c axis (Fig. 3). In the crystals of (2), the molecules are linked through intermolecular hydrogen bonds of N–H···O, C–H···O and C–H···N, forming layers parallel to the ac plane (Fig. 4).

IR spectra of <italic>(1)</italic> and <italic>(2)</italic>

The IR spectra of (1) and (2) show two very strong bands, centered, respectively, at 2,072 and 2,093 cm−1, assigned to the vibrations of the end-to-end and end-on azide bridges. The stretching vibrations of the C=N bonds in the two complexes are at 1,616 and 1,618 cm−1, respectively. The very strong absorption bands centered at 1,115 cm−1 for (1) and for (2) are assigned to the perchlorate anions.

Urease inhibitory activities

From Table 3, we observe that the complexes show potent urease inhibitory activities with the IC50 values being lower than that of the acetohydroxamic acid co-assayed as a positive reference against the enzyme. All of the complexes possess stronger urease inhibitory activities than those of the corresponding ligands, and yet possess lower urease inhibitory activities than that of copper(II) perchlorate. The complex (1) possesses slightly lower urease inhibitory activity than that of complex (2). The Schiff base ligands show no inhibitory activities on jack bean urease (IC50 > 100 μM), which is accord with the results which we reported recently [10, 11].

Conclusions

It is evident from the above discussion that the steric effects of the ligands can influence the coordination modes of the azide co-ligands. The urease inhibitory activities show that such complexes could be potential urease inhibitors.

elements.content: A pair of azido-bridged Schiff base copper complexes, [CuL1(μ1,3-N3)]n · nClO4(1) and [Cu2(L2)2(μ1,1-N3)2] · 2ClO4(2) (L1 = N,N-diethyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, L2 = N-isopropyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine) have been obtained by the same synthetic procedures, but with slightly different Schiff bases. The structures of the complexes have been characterized by IR spectra, elemental analysis, and single crystal X-ray determination. Each Cu atom in the complexes is five-coordinate in a square pyramidal configuration involving the three N atoms of the Schiff base ligand and two N atoms from two bridging azide ligands. The azide ligands adopt end-to-end bridging mode in (1), and end-on bridging mode in (2). The different coordination modes of the azide ligands in the two complexes are assigned to the steric effects of the terminal groups (two ethyl groups for (1) and one isopropyl group for (2)) in the Schiff base ligands. The urease inhibitory activities of the complexes were evaluated. Both of them showed potent inhibition against jack bean urease.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A pair of azido-bridged Schiff base copper complexes, [CuL1(μ1,3-N3)]n ⋅ nClO4(1) and [Cu2(L2)2(μ1,1-N3)2] ⋅ 2ClO4(2) (L1 = N,N-diethyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, L2 = N-isopropyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine) have been obtained by the same synthetic procedures, but with slightly different Schiff bases. The structures of the complexes have been characterized by IR spectra, elemental analysis, and single crystal X-ray determination. Each Cu atom in the complexes is five-coordinate in a square pyramidal configuration involving the three N atoms of the Schiff base ligand and two N atoms from two bridging azide ligands. The azide ligands adopt end-to-end bridging mode in (1), and end-on bridging mode in (2). The different coordination modes of the azide ligands in the two complexes are assigned to the steric effects of the terminal groups (two ethyl groups for (1) and one isopropyl group for (2)) in the Schiff base ligands. The urease inhibitory activities of the complexes were evaluated. Both of them showed potent inhibition against jack bean urease.

elements.content: Polynuclear complexes containing bridging ligands are of interest because of their versatile molecular structures, as well as the fact that they may be designed with specific functionalities [1–3]. Among pseudohalogens, azide is the most extensively studied building blocks in polynuclear complexes due to its versatility and probability of functioning as a bridging ligand to give varieties of coordination modes [4–6]. A major obstacle to a more comprehensive study of such azide-based polymeric coordination complexes is the lack of rational synthetic procedures, since with the present state of knowledge it is hardly possible to determine which coordination mode will be adopted by the azide ligand, and what final structures will be formed [7–9]. Appropriate modification of the ligands makes it possible to construct new structures of the complexes with useful properties. Recently, we have reported the urease inhibitory activities of several Schiff base complexes [10, 11]. We report herein the synthesis, crystal structures, and urease inhibitory activities of a pair of azido-bridged Schiff base copper complexes, [CuL1(μ1,3-N3)]n · nClO4(1) and [Cu2(L2)2(μ1,1-N3)2] · 2ClO4(2) (L1 = N,N-diethyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, L2 = N-isopropyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polynuclear complexes containing bridging ligands are of interest because of their versatile molecular structures, as well as the fact that they may be designed with specific functionalities [1-3]. Among pseudohalogens, azide is the most extensively studied building blocks in polynuclear complexes due to its versatility and probability of functioning as a bridging ligand to give varieties of coordination modes [4-6]. A major obstacle to a more comprehensive study of such azide-based polymeric coordination complexes is the lack of rational synthetic procedures, since with the present state of knowledge it is hardly possible to determine which coordination mode will be adopted by the azide ligand, and what final structures will be formed [7-9]. Appropriate modification of the ligands makes it possible to construct new structures of the complexes with useful properties. Recently, we have reported the urease inhibitory activities of several Schiff base complexes [10, 11]. We report herein the synthesis, crystal structures, and urease inhibitory activities of a pair of azido-bridged Schiff base copper complexes, [CuL1(μ1,3-N3)]n ⋅ nClO4(1) and [Cu2(L2)2(μ1,1-N3)2] ⋅ 2ClO4(2) (L1 = N,N-diethyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, L2 = N-isopropyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylmethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine).

elements.content: High purity 2-pyridylaldehyde, N,N-diethylethane-1,2-diamine, and N-isopropylethane-1,2-diamine were purchased from Aldrich and were used as received. All other reagents were of analytical grade. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) were performed using a Perkin–Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet AVATAR 360 spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4,000–400 cm−1 region.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and measurements

High purity 2-pyridylaldehyde, N,N-diethylethane-1,2-diamine, and N-isopropylethane-1,2-diamine were purchased from Aldrich and were used as received. All other reagents were of analytical grade. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) were performed using a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet AVATAR 360 spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4,000-400 cm-1 region.

elements.content: The ligands L1 and L2 were prepared by stirring equimolar amounts (1.0 mmol each) of 2-pyridylaldehyde with N,N-diethylethane-1,2-diamine, and N-isopropylethane-1,2-diamine, respectively, in 50 mL of methanol using literature methods [12, 13]. Yields: 97% for L1 and 95% for L2. Anal. Calcd. for C12H19N3 (L1): C, 70.2; H, 9.3; N, 20.5%. Found C, 70.0; H, 9.4; N, 20.4%. Anal. Calcd. for C11H17N3 (L2): C, 69.1; H, 9.0; N, 22.0%. Found C, 69.3; H, 9.1; N, 21.9%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of ligands L1 and L2

The ligands L1 and L2 were prepared by stirring equimolar amounts (1.0 mmol each) of 2-pyridylaldehyde with N,N-diethylethane-1,2-diamine, and N-isopropylethane-1,2-diamine, respectively, in 50 mL of methanol using literature methods [12, 13]. Yields: 97% for L1 and 95% for L2. Anal. Calcd. for C12H19N3 (L1): C, 70.2; H, 9.3; N, 20.5%. Found C, 70.0; H, 9.4; N, 20.4%. Anal. Calcd. for C11H17N3 (L2): C, 69.1; H, 9.0; N, 22.0%. Found C, 69.3; H, 9.1; N, 21.9%.

elements.content: An aqueous solution (2 mL) of copper(II) perchlorate hexahydrate (0.1 mmol) was added to a methanolic solution (8 mL) of L1 (0.1 mmol) and stirred at room temperature for 10 min. Then an aqueous solution (2 mL) of sodium azide (0.2 mmol) was added dropwise with continuous stirring. The mixture was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature to give a deep blue solution. Suitable blue single crystals for the structure determination were obtained by slow evaporation of the resulting solution in air. Yield: 67% on the basis of L1. Anal. calc. for C12H19ClCuN6O4: C, 35.13; H, 4.67; N, 20.48; found: C, 35.32; H, 4.73; N, 20.27%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [CuL1(μ1,3-N3)]n ⋅ nClO4(1)

An aqueous solution (2 mL) of copper(II) perchlorate hexahydrate (0.1 mmol) was added to a methanolic solution (8 mL) of L1 (0.1 mmol) and stirred at room temperature for 10 min. Then an aqueous solution (2 mL) of sodium azide (0.2 mmol) was added dropwise with continuous stirring. The mixture was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature to give a deep blue solution. Suitable blue single crystals for the structure determination were obtained by slow evaporation of the resulting solution in air. Yield: 67% on the basis of L1. Anal. calc. for C12H19ClCuN6O4: C, 35.13; H, 4.67; N, 20.48; found: C, 35.32; H, 4.73; N, 20.27%.

elements.content: A procedure identical to that described for the preparation of (1), but with L1 replaced by L2, produced the blue single crystals of (2). Yield: 45% on the basis of L2. Anal. calc. for C11H17ClCuN6O4: C, 33.34; H, 4.32; N, 21.21; found: C, 33.12; H, 4.38; N, 21.33%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Cu2(L2)2(μ1,1-N3)2] ⋅ 2ClO4(2)

A procedure identical to that described for the preparation of (1), but with L1 replaced by L2, produced the blue single crystals of (2). Yield: 45% on the basis of L2. Anal. calc. for C11H17ClCuN6O4: C, 33.34; H, 4.32; N, 21.21; found: C, 33.12; H, 4.38; N, 21.33%.

elements.content: Diffraction intensities for the complexes were collected at 298(2) K using a Bruker SMART APEX 1000 area-detector with MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The collected data were reduced using the SAINT program [14], and empirical absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS program [15]. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined against F2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL program [16]. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Atom H3A attached to N3 in (2) was located in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically, with N–H distance restrained to 0.90(1) Å. All other H atoms were placed in calculated positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. The crystallographic data for the complexes are summarized in Table 1. CCDC reference numbers 638039 for (1) and 638104 for (2) (Table 2).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Diffraction intensities for the complexes were collected at 298(2) K using a Bruker SMART APEX 1000 area-detector with MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The collected data were reduced using the SAINT program [14], and empirical absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS program [15]. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined against F2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL program [16]. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Atom H3A attached to N3 in (2) was located in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically, with N-H distance restrained to 0.90(1) Å. All other H atoms were placed in calculated positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. The crystallographic data for the complexes are summarized in Table 1. CCDC reference numbers 638039 for (1) and 638104 for (2) (Table 2).

The measurement of urease inhibitory activities was carried out according to the method reported by Tanaka [17]. Generally, the assay mixture, containing 25 μL of jack bean urease (10 kU/L) and 25 μL of the tested complexes of various concentrations (dissolved in the solution of DMSO:H2O = 1:1 (v/v)), was preincubated for 1 h at 37 °C in a 96-well assay plate. Then 0.2 mL of 100 mM Hepes (N-[2-hydroxyethyl]piperazine-N′-[2-ethanesulfonic acid]) buffer at pH 6.8 [18] containing 500 mM urea and 0.002% phenol red were added and incubated at 37 °C. The reaction time, which was required to produce enough ammonium carbonate to raise the pH of a Hepes buffer from 6.8 to 7.7, was measured by a micro-plate reader (570 nm) with the end-point being determined by the color of phenol red indicator. The results concerning the inhibition of the complexes, of their corresponding ligands, and of copper(II) perchlorate on jack bean urease are summarized in Table 3.

Urease inhibitory test

The measurement of urease inhibitory activities was carried out according to the method reported by Tanaka [17]. Generally, the assay mixture, containing 25 μL of jack bean urease (10 kU/L) and 25 μL of the tested complexes of various concentrations (dissolved in the solution of DMSO:H2O = 1:1 (v/v)), was preincubated for 1 h at 37 °C in a 96-well assay plate. Then 0.2 mL of 100 mM Hepes (N-[2-hydroxyethyl]piperazine-N'-[2-ethanesulfonic acid]) buffer at pH 6.8 [18] containing 500 mM urea and 0.002% phenol red were added and incubated at 37 °C. The reaction time, which was required to produce enough ammonium carbonate to raise the pH of a Hepes buffer from 6.8 to 7.7, was measured by a micro-plate reader (570 nm) with the end-point being determined by the color of phenol red indicator. The results concerning the inhibition of the complexes, of their corresponding ligands, and of copper(II) perchlorate on jack bean urease are summarized in Table 3.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The Schiff base ligands L1 and L2 are yellow oils, that readily dissolve in methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile. The two copper complexes (as illustrated in Schemes 1 and 2) form blue block-shaped crystals, which are stable in air at room temperature, soluble in methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile, insoluble in water and diethyl ether.

elements.content: The two complexes were synthesized easily under identical synthetic procedures. The synthesis of the complexes here demonstrates that the steric effects of the ligands can influence the coordination modes of the bridging azide ligands. The azide ligands in (1) adopt end-to-end coordination mode, while in (2), the azide ligands adopt end-on coordination mode, which we assign to the greater steric effects of the diethyl group of L1 compared to the isopropyl group of L2.

The synthesis of the complexes here demonstrates that the steric effects of the ligands can influence the coordination modes of the bridging azide ligands. The azide ligands in (1) adopt end-to-end coordination mode, while in (2), the azide ligands adopt end-on coordination mode, which we assign to the greater steric effects of the diethyl group of L1 compared to the isopropyl group of L2.

elements.content: Figures 1 and 2 give perspective views of the complexes (1) and (2) together with the atomic labeling system. Complex (1) is an end-to-end azido-bridged polynuclear copper(II) compound, while complex (2) is a double end-on azido-bridged centrosymmetric dinuclear compound. Each Cu atom in the complexes has square pyramidal coordination and is coordinated by the three N atoms of the Schiff base ligand, and by one terminal N atom of one bridging azide ligand, defining the basal plane, and by one terminal N atom of another bridging azide ligand, occupying the apical position.
elements.clean_text:
Structures of (1) and (2)

Figures 1 and 2 give perspective views of the complexes (1) and (2) together with the atomic labeling system. Complex (1) is an end-to-end azido-bridged polynuclear copper(II) compound, while complex (2) is a double end-on azido-bridged centrosymmetric dinuclear compound. Each Cu atom in the complexes has square pyramidal coordination and is coordinated by the three N atoms of the Schiff base ligand, and by one terminal N atom of one bridging azide ligand, defining the basal plane, and by one terminal N atom of another bridging azide ligand, occupying the apical position.

elements.content: The bond lengths subtended at the metal centers are comparable with those observed in other Schiff base-copper(II) complexes [19–21]. It is notable that the apical bond lengths [2.325(3) Å for (1) and 2.536(3) Å for (2)] are much longer than those of the corresponding basal bonds (Table 1). As expected, the bonds involving amine atom N3 [2.071(3) Å for (1), 2.059(3) Å for (2)] are longer than those involving imine atom N2 [1.960(3) Å for (1), 1.954(3) Å for (2)]. Each bridging azide ligand is nearly linear and shows bent coordination mode with the metal atoms. The Cu···Cu distance is 5.659(2) Å in (1) and 3.384(2) Å in (2), respectively.

Each bridging azide ligand is nearly linear and shows bent coordination mode with the metal atoms. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance is 5.659(2) Å in (1) and 3.384(2) Å in (2), respectively.

The complex (1) possesses slightly lower urease inhibitory activity than that of complex (2). The Schiff base ligands show no inhibitory activities on jack bean urease (IC50 > 100 μM), which is accord with the results which we reported recently [10, 11].

elements.content: It is evident from the above discussion that the steric effects of the ligands can influence the coordination modes of the azide co-ligands. The urease inhibitory activities show that such complexes could be potential urease inhibitors.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

It is evident from the above discussion that the steric effects of the ligands can influence the coordination modes of the azide co-ligands. The urease inhibitory activities show that such complexes could be potential urease inhibitors.

The ligands L1 and L2 were prepared by stirring equimolar amounts (1.0 mmol each) of 2-pyridylaldehyde with N,N-diethylethane-1,2-diamine, and N-isopropylethane-1,2-diamine, respectively, in 50 mL of methanol using literature methods [12, 13]. Yields: 97% for L1 and 95% for L2. Anal. Calcd. for C12H19N3 (L1): C, 70.2; H, 9.3; N, 20.5%. Found C, 70.0; H, 9.4; N, 20.4%. Anal. Calcd. for C11H17N3 (L2): C, 69.1; H, 9.0; N, 22.0%. Found C, 69.3; H, 9.1; N, 21.9%.

Preparation of [CuL1(μ<sub>1,3</sub>-N<sub>3</sub>)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> · <italic>n</italic>ClO<sub>4</sub><italic>(1)</italic>

An aqueous solution (2 mL) of copper(II) perchlorate hexahydrate (0.1 mmol) was added to a methanolic solution (8 mL) of L1 (0.1 mmol) and stirred at room temperature for 10 min. Then an aqueous solution (2 mL) of sodium azide (0.2 mmol) was added dropwise with continuous stirring. The mixture was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature to give a deep blue solution. Suitable blue single crystals for the structure determination were obtained by slow evaporation of the resulting solution in air. Yield: 67% on the basis of L1. Anal. calc. for C12H19ClCuN6O4: C, 35.13; H, 4.67; N, 20.48; found: C, 35.32; H, 4.73; N, 20.27%.

Preparation of [Cu<sub>2</sub>(L2)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>1,1</sub>-N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>] · 2ClO<sub>4</sub><italic>(2)</italic>

A procedure identical to that described for the preparation of (1), but with L1 replaced by L2, produced the blue single crystals of (2). Yield: 45% on the basis of L2. Anal. calc. for C11H17ClCuN6O4: C, 33.34; H, 4.32; N, 21.21; found: C, 33.12; H, 4.38; N, 21.33%.

Yields: 97% for L1 and 95% for L2. Anal. Calcd. for C12H19N3 (L1): C, 70.2; H, 9.3; N, 20.5%. Found C, 70.0; H, 9.4; N, 20.4%. Anal. Calcd. for C11H17N3 (L2): C, 69.1; H, 9.0; N, 22.0%. Found C, 69.3; H, 9.1; N, 21.9%.

Preparation of [CuL1(μ1,3-N3)]n ⋅ nClO4(1)

An aqueous solution (2 mL) of copper(II) perchlorate hexahydrate (0.1 mmol) was added to a methanolic solution (8 mL) of L1 (0.1 mmol) and stirred at room temperature for 10 min. Then an aqueous solution (2 mL) of sodium azide (0.2 mmol) was added dropwise with continuous stirring. The mixture was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature to give a deep blue solution. Suitable blue single crystals for the structure determination were obtained by slow evaporation of the resulting solution in air. Yield: 67% on the basis of L1. Anal. calc. for C12H19ClCuN6O4: C, 35.13; H, 4.67; N, 20.48; found: C, 35.32; H, 4.73; N, 20.27%.

Preparation of [Cu2(L2)2(μ1,1-N3)2] ⋅ 2ClO4(2)

A procedure identical to that described for the preparation of (1), but with L1 replaced by L2, produced the blue single crystals of (2). Yield: 45% on the basis of L2. Anal. calc. for C11H17ClCuN6O4: C, 33.34; H, 4.32; N, 21.21; found: C, 33.12; H, 4.38; N, 21.33%.
